description: Exceeding the prescribed speed limits on roads. Speed limits vary by road type and vehicle category. Urban areas: 50 km/h, Highways: 80-100 km/h depending on vehicle type.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 2,000 for first offense, Rs. 4,000 for repeat offenses
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 1,000 for first offense, Rs. 2,000 for repeat offenses
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 1,000 - 2,000, license may be suspended for 3 months
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 1,500 for first offense, Rs. 3,000 for repeat offenses

notes: Speed limits: Urban areas - 50 km/h, Highways - 80-100 km/h depending on vehicle type. Heavy vehicles have lower limits. Repeat offenses may result in license suspension.

description: Driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs is a serious criminal offense with severe penalties. Blood alcohol limit: 0.03% (30 mg per 100 ml).

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 10,000 fine + 6 months imprisonment (first offense), Rs. 15,000 + 2 years (repeat)

notes: First offense: Rs. 10,000 fine + 6 months imprisonment. Repeat offense: Rs. 15,000 + 2 years imprisonment. License may be suspended or cancelled. Zero tolerance policy in many states.

description: Drivers and front-seat passengers must wear seat belts while the vehicle is in motion. This is mandatory for safety and violation attracts penalties.

stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 1,000, applicable to both driver and front-seat passenger
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 1,000, license may be suspended for repeat offenses
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 1,000, fine applies to both driver and passenger
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 1,000, mandatory for all front-seat occupants

notes: Applicable to driver and front-seat passenger. Not wearing seat belt is a traffic violation. Some states may suspend license for repeat offenses.

description: Riding a two-wheeler without a helmet is mandatory for both driver and pillion rider. Helmet must be ISI certified and properly fastened.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 1,000, license suspended for 3 months on repeat offense
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 1,000 for rider, Rs. 500 for pillion
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 1,000, license suspension for repeat violations
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 1,000, both rider and pillion must wear helmet
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 1,000, helmet must be ISI certified

notes: Helmet must be ISI certified. Both rider and pillion must wear helmets. License may be suspended for 3 months on repeat offense. Some states have different fines for rider and pillion.

description: Carrying more than two people (including driver) on a two-wheeler is illegal. Only driver and one pillion rider are allowed.

stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 2,000, only driver and one pillion allowed

notes: Only driver and one pillion rider are allowed on two-wheelers. Carrying more than two people is dangerous and illegal. Fine is Rs. 2,000. Vehicle may be impounded.

description: Violating traffic signals, especially jumping red lights, is a serious traffic offense. Red light violation is dangerous and can cause accidents.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000, license may be suspended for 3 months
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 5,000, license suspension for repeat offenses

notes: Red light violation is dangerous and can cause accidents. Fine is Rs. 5,000 for first offense. Some states may have higher penalties for repeat offenses. Camera-based enforcement is common in metro cities.

description: Using a mobile phone while driving is prohibited and attracts penalties. This includes talking, texting, or any other use of mobile phone while driving.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000 first offense, Rs. 10,000 repeat offense, license suspension
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 5,000, license may be suspended for 3 months
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 5,000, license suspension for repeat violations

notes: Using mobile phone includes talking, texting, or any other use. Hands-free devices are allowed but not recommended. First offense: Rs. 5,000. Repeat offense: Rs. 10,000. License may be suspended.

description: Pollution Under Control (PUC) certificate is mandatory. Driving without a valid PUC certificate attracts penalties. PUC must be renewed periodically.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 10,000, vehicle may be impounded until PUC obtained
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 10,000, certificate must be renewed every 6 months (BS-IV) or annually (BS-VI)
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 10,000, vehicle cannot be used without valid PUC
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 10,000, PUC centers available at authorized locations

notes: PUC certificate must be renewed periodically. For BS-IV vehicles: every 6 months, for BS-VI: every year. Certificate can be obtained from authorized PUC centers. Fine is uniform across India.

description: Third-party insurance is mandatory for all motor vehicles in India. Driving without valid insurance is a punishable offense. Comprehensive insurance is recommended for better coverage.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 2,000, vehicle may be impounded if insurance not valid
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 2,000, vehicle cannot be driven without valid insurance
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 2,000, insurance must be renewed before expiry

notes: Third-party insurance is compulsory. Comprehensive insurance is recommended for better coverage. Vehicle may be impounded if insurance is not valid. Insurance must be renewed before expiry.

description: Parking in no-parking zones, blocking traffic, or parking in disabled parking spaces without authorization. Parking violations vary by location and severity.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 500-1,000, vehicle may be towed, higher fines in metro areas
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 500-1,000, vehicle clamping in some areas

notes: Parking violations vary by location. Blocking traffic or parking in no-parking zones attracts fines. Metro cities may have higher penalties. Vehicle may be towed or clamped. Disabled parking violation: Rs. 1,000.

description: Not following lane discipline, changing lanes without indicators, or driving in wrong lanes. Proper lane discipline is essential for road safety.

stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 500, camera-based enforcement on major roads
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 500, some states may impose higher penalties

notes: Proper lane discipline is essential for road safety. Use indicators before changing lanes. Standard fine is Rs. 500. Some states may impose higher penalties on highways.

description: Driving on the wrong side of the road or against traffic flow is illegal and extremely dangerous.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000, license may be suspended for 3 months

notes: Wrong side driving is a major cause of accidents. License may be suspended for 3 months. Repeat offenses may result in license cancellation.

description: Driving in a manner that endangers life or is likely to cause harm to any person. This includes reckless driving, racing, and other dangerous behaviors.

stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 5,000 + imprisonment, repeat offense: higher penalty

notes: Dangerous driving includes reckless driving, racing, and behaviors that endanger life. Fine: Rs. 5,000 + 6 months imprisonment. License may be suspended or cancelled. Repeat offenses have higher penalties.

description: Overtaking from wrong side, overtaking at curves, or violating safe overtaking procedures. Overtaking must be done from right side and only when safe.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000, dangerous overtaking can result in license suspension
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 5,000, never overtake at curves or bridges
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 5,000, overtaking from left is illegal

notes: Overtaking must be done from right side. Never overtake at curves, bridges, or in no-overtaking zones. Dangerous overtaking can result in license suspension. Fine is Rs. 5,000.

description: Vehicles must display valid registration number plates as per prescribed format and specifications. Number plates must be clearly visible and comply with HSRP norms.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000, vehicle may be impounded until proper number plate is fixed
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 5,000, HSRP mandatory for all vehicles
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 5,000, number plates must be clearly visible
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 5,000, vehicle cannot be used without proper number plate

notes: Number plates must be clearly visible, properly fixed, and comply with High Security Registration Plate (HSRP) norms. Vehicle may be impounded until proper number plate is fixed.

description: Operating a motor vehicle without a valid driving license is a serious offense under the Motor Vehicles Act 1988. License must be valid and appropriate for vehicle category.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000, vehicle may be impounded, possible imprisonment
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 5,000, subsequent offenses may result in higher penalties
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 5,000, license must match vehicle category
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 5,000, first offense: Rs. 5,000, repeat: higher penalty

notes: First offense: Rs. 5,000. Subsequent offenses may result in higher penalties and possible imprisonment. License must be valid and appropriate for vehicle category. Vehicle may be impounded.

description: Driving with an expired driving license is illegal. License must be renewed before expiry. Driving with expired license attracts penalties.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000, license must be renewed before expiry
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 5,000, grace period may apply for renewal
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 5,000, license renewal can be done online

description: Driving a vehicle without a valid Registration Certificate or with an expired RC is illegal. RC must be renewed before expiry and must be carried while driving.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000, vehicle may be impounded until RC obtained
stateVariations.Karnataka: Rs. 5,000, RC must be renewed before expiry
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 5,000, driving with expired RC attracts penalty
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 5,000, some states may charge Rs. 2,000 for first offense
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 5,000, vehicle cannot be driven without valid RC

description: Leaving the scene of an accident without providing assistance or information is a serious criminal offense. Hit and run cases attract severe penalties including imprisonment.

stateVariations.Maharashtra: Rs. 5,000 + 6 months to 2 years imprisonment, license cancellation
stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 5,000 + 6 months to 2 years imprisonment, license suspension
stateVariations.Tamil Nadu: Rs. 5,000 + imprisonment, repeat offense: higher penalty
stateVariations.Gujarat: Rs. 5,000 + 6 months to 2 years imprisonment, license cancellation

description: Not following traffic signals, ignoring signals, or violating signal rules is a traffic offense.
notes: Traffic signals must be followed. Red means stop, yellow means caution, green means go. Fine is Rs. 5,000. License may be suspended for repeat offenses.

stateVariations.Delhi: Rs. 1,000, camera-based enforcement at major crossings
